docs.snippet: Argentina could be allowed as much as three months to reimburse the four Latin American countries that helped it through its interest-payment crisis last weekend, Jesus Silva Herzog, the Finance Minister of Mexico, said here today.    Mr. Silva, whom...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina could be allowed as much as three months to reimburse the four Latin American countries that helped it through its interest-payment crisis last weekend, Jesus Silva Herzog, the Finance Minister of Mexico, said here today. Mr. Silva, whom Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan cited as the architect of the $500 million loan agreement for Argentina, said he expected Argentina to meet the 30-day repayment deadline that the participants in the agreement reported Saturday. If not, however, the deadline can be stretched for 60 days, he said. He also emphasized the significance of four debtor nations' contributing to assist a fifth.

docs.snippet: After four months in office and an international flurry over a near default in its interest payments abroad, Argentina's new Government is still unable to decide the exact size and breakdown of its foreign debt or how much it is willing to recognize....
docs.lead_paragraph: After four months in office and an international flurry over a near default in its interest payments abroad, Argentina's new Government is still unable to decide the exact size and breakdown of its foreign debt or how much it is willing to recognize. Although the country is listed as having the third-largest foreign debt in the developing world, after Brazil and Mexico, Argentina's previous military regime apparently kept no central records and left behind what Government officials and financial experts have described as an ''administrative nightmare.'' ''We still don't know the debt - there were no registers in the central bank,'' said Bernardo Grinspun, Argentina's Economics Minister, before leaving Friday night for the United States for crucial debt talks with the International Monetary Fund. ''With most loans,'' Mr. Grinspun said, ''we could not identify the purpose, the amount, the interest or the grace period.''

headline.main: ARGENTINA UNSURE HOW MUCH DEBT IS

byline.original: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Uruguay's military Government has closed the opposition newspaper Cinco Dias and magazine Frente Amplia, the editor of Cinco Dias said Saturday.   Cinco Dias has been published for less than a month and the first edition of Frente Amplia came out...
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay's military Government has closed the opposition newspaper Cinco Dias and magazine Frente Amplia, the editor of Cinco Dias said Saturday. Cinco Dias has been published for less than a month and the first edition of Frente Amplia came out this week.

headline.main: Uruguay Government Closes Two Opposition Publications

docs.snippet: Otto Arosemena Gomez, an Ecuadoran lawyer and legislator who served as Provisional President in Quito for two years, died Friday of a heart attack in the ocean resort of Salinas, Ecuador, Reuters reported yesterday, citing family sources in Quito. He...
docs.lead_paragraph: Otto Arosemena Gomez, an Ecuadoran lawyer and legislator who served as Provisional President in Quito for two years, died Friday of a heart attack in the ocean resort of Salinas, Ecuador, Reuters reported yesterday, citing family sources in Quito. He was 58 years old. Mr. Arosemena's stint as chief of state from November 1966 through August 1968 was marked by sharp differences with the United States over its economic treatment of Latin America.

headline.kicker: OTTO AROSEMENA, 58, IS DEAD IN ECUADOR

docs.lead_paragraph: Msgr. Robert J. Fox, associate pastor of St. Paul's Church in East Harlem and former coordinator of the Spanish Community Action program in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died Friday of circulatory disease at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 54 years old.

docs.snippet: The boycott of the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow was called by President Carter to protest the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. These are the 54 nations and territories that participated in the boycott, according to the United States Olympic...
docs.lead_paragraph: The boycott of the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow was called by President Carter to protest the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. These are the 54 nations and territories that participated in the boycott, according to the United States Olympic Committee in Colorado Springs. Albania Antigua Argentina Bahamas Bahrain Bangladesh Belize Bermuda Bolivia Canada Cayman Islands Chad Chile China Egypt El Salvador Fiji Gambia Germany, West Ghana Haiti Honduras Hong Kong Indonesia Israel Japan Kenya Liberia Liechtenstein Malawi Malaysia Mauritius Monaco Morocco Nicaragua Norway Pakistan Papua New Guinea Paraguay Philippines Saudi Arabia Singapore Somalia South Korea Sudan Swaziland Taiwan Thailand Tunisia Turkey United States Uruguay Virgin Islands Zaire

docs.snippet: Yannick Noah, seeded third, became the latest of a string of upset victims in the Italian Open tennis championships today when he lost a third-round match to an unseeded player, Diego Perez of Uruguay, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4.  The loss by Noah, rated sixth in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Yannick Noah, seeded third, became the latest of a string of upset victims in the Italian Open tennis championships today when he lost a third-round match to an unseeded player, Diego Perez of Uruguay, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4. The loss by Noah, rated sixth in the world, left only 2 of the top 10 seeded players still competing on the clay courts of Rome's Foro Italico. They are Andres Gomez, seeded fifth, who advanced to the quarterfinals by beating Anders Jarryd, and Jose-Luis Clerc, No. 8, who beat Gianni Ocleppo.

docs.snippet: Aaron Krickstein, at age 16 the youngest semifinalist in the history of the Italian Open tennis championships, and fifth-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador advanced to the final today.    Krickstein overpowered Diego Perez of Uruguay, 6-4, 6-0, and Gomez...
docs.lead_paragraph: Aaron Krickstein, at age 16 the youngest semifinalist in the history of the Italian Open tennis championships, and fifth-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador advanced to the final today. Krickstein overpowered Diego Perez of Uruguay, 6-4, 6-0, and Gomez beat Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina, 6-3, 6-2. Rarely leaving the baseline, Krickstein, who is from Grosse Point, Mich., and ranks 66th in the world, kept the 22-year-old Perez back with deep forehands and two-handed backhands. He took a 3-0 lead, let Perez get back to 5-4, then finished off the set.

docs.snippet: Dozens of people were wounded in central Montevideo today when antiriot policemen dispersed a banned march of thousands of people demonstrating for political amnesty and freedom of the press, witnesses said.   They said several people were detained...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dozens of people were wounded in central Montevideo today when antiriot policemen dispersed a banned march of thousands of people demonstrating for political amnesty and freedom of the press, witnesses said. They said several people were detained but this was not confirmed by the police. Security forces, backed by armored vehicles and policemen on horseback, moved in repeatedly to disperse the march along the capital's main avenue, the witnesses said.

headline.main: Dozens Wounded as Police Disperse March in Uruguay

docs.snippet: Torture is the dirty little secret of modern politics, and typically, victims are punished not only for real or imagined crimes, but also because they know the secret. They die, or ''disappear,'' or languish in jail for years to prevent their bearing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Torture is the dirty little secret of modern politics, and typically, victims are punished not only for real or imagined crimes, but also because they know the secret. They die, or ''disappear,'' or languish in jail for years to prevent their bearing witness against the degrading use of technology to smash bodies and bend minds. In Uruguay, for example, why else has Hiber Conteris been denied a fair trial in open court? A 50- year-old Methodist minister, Mr. Conteris, was arrested in 1976 on his return from a church conference in Europe. He was charged with ''assault upon the Constitution'' and ''criminal'' association with suspect subversives. To secure a confession, he was hung from the wrist, burned and submerged in filthy sewage.
